sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Kuwait is a small but wealthy country located in Western Asia along the Persian Gulf. It is known for its vast oil reserves, modern skyline, and strong cultural traditions.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Kuwait City is the capital and largest city of Kuwait. It serves as the country’s political, economic, and cultural center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of Kuwait is the Kuwaiti dinar (KWD), one of the highest-valued currencies in the world.

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Arabic. English is widely spoken, especially in business and education.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Kuwaiti cuisine reflects Arabian and Persian influences, with popular dishes such as machboos, mutabbaq samak, and harees.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Kuwait has mostly flat desert terrain with a short coastline along the Persian Gulf. It experiences extremely hot summers.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Kuwaiti culture places strong importance on family, hospitality, and Islamic traditions, while also embracing modern lifestyles.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourist attractions include the Kuwait Towers, Grand Mosque, Souq Al-Mubarakiya, and modern shopping districts.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Kuwait’s currency is often ranked as the strongest currency in the world by value.

history.event: Kuwait was established as a trading port and fishing settlement.
Kuwait became a British protectorate to secure its autonomy.
Oil was discovered, transforming Kuwait’s economy and society.
Kuwait gained independence from the United Kingdom.
Iraq invaded Kuwait, leading to the Gulf War.
Kuwait was liberated following an international coalition effort.
